## Recap

-   [**Data**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"} can be thought of as a list of values.

-   These values are [**observations**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"} on [**observational units**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"}, of a series of [**variables**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"}.

    -   The [**semantics**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"} of data are the meanings behind the values.
    
    -   The [**structure**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"} of data is how the values are arranged and displayed.
    
-   Variables can be classified into [**numerical**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"} and [**categorical**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"} (aka [**quantatiative**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"} and [**qualitative**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"}).

    -   Numerical data can be subdivided into [**discrete**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"} and [**continuous**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"}; categorical data can be subdivided into [**ordinal**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"} and [**nominal**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"}.
    
    
## Leadup

-   Today, we'll talk extensively about the structure of data.

-   First, I'd like to further motivate our discussion of data science by introducing the so-called [**data science lifecycle**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"}.

-   There are many variations of the data science lifecycle (DSLC).


## The Data Science Lifecycle

![](cycle.svg){width="80%"}


## The Data Science Lifecycle

-   The exact steps aren't all that important.

-   Rather, the main idea conveyed by the data science lifecycle is a _cycle_; that is, an _iterative_ process through which progress is made.

-   Two main entry points: with a _question_ or with a _dataset_.

    -   When you start with a question, it is up to you to find an appropriate dataset (or collection of datasets) to answer your question.
    
    -   When you start with a dataset, you will (ultimately) need to figure out what sorts of questions it be used to can answer.

## The Data Science Lifecycle

::::{.columns}

:::{.column width="50%"}

-   Regardless of whether you start with a dataset or a question, you will likely need to, after exploration and analysis, revise your question and/or find new datasets.
:::

:::{.column width="50%"}
:::{.fragment}
![](meme1.png)
:::
:::

::::


-   Eventually, you will reach a point where you can put your thoughts and findings together in the form of a coherent [**report**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"} (or [**presentation**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"}), at which point you report your findings and break out of the cycle.

## Leadup

-   Okay, let's talk a bit about data structure.

-   Since data consists of observations on one or more variables, it is very common to store data in a [**tabular**]{style="color:#fa8b2f"} format.

-   To help ground our discussion, let's consider the `AirPassengers` dataset (which is one of the built-in datasets in `R`).

    -   This dataset contains observations on the monthly totals of international airline passengers between the years of 1949 and 1960, inclusive.
    
## `AirPassengers`

-   Same data as before... right?

## `AirPassengers`

-   Well, same data _semantics_, right?

-   Let's explicitly state the values, variables, and observations.

    -   There are 144 observations; one for each month between January 1949 and December 1960
    -   There are two variables: months (which takes values in the set \{`Jan`, `Feb`, ..., `Nov`, `Dec`\}) and years (which takes values in the set \{1949, 1950, ..., 1959, 1960\}).
    
-   The second way of expressing the `AirPassengers` dataset makes the variables a little more clear.

## Leadup

-   We will return to this dataset in a bit.

-   For now, I just wanted to point out that there are potentially many different ways to _structure_ the same dataset.

-   As one might imagine, this can lead to problems! 

-   It would be nice to have a system/standard which we could use to make different sets more _comparable_. Thankfully, such a system exists:

# Tidy Data {background-color="black" background-image="https://media3.giphy.com/media/95pCDbEGyLuUg/giphy.gif?cid=ecf05e4762cmk714qxdkzigyc7jftpump6figqpl3cfag7lc&ep=v1_gifs_related&rid=giphy.gif&ct=g"}

## Tidy Data
